wp:comment.wp:comment_content: *I am not clear with these videos.:( * *2D moving reference- I first thought it's a circular motion with slipping on a circular path. But it's like two circular motions with different radius adding together. *Angular momentum p1- It would be rotation as long as acceleration of object always point toward the same point? *Angular momentum p2- How is it different from vibrational motion with spring linking towards center? *Bouncing ball- Is it due to energy conservation-momentum conservation-second law? *Chasles's theorem- The different length of links result in rotation of rectangular object? And we are moving it upward but not like swinging it? *Impact force- Is it connect to particle's internal interaction, like different liquid? *Instant center- So it's an arc motion? *Gyroscope- Why isn't there 2 dampers in the x direction but using normal force or spring force to keep it in equilibrium? *Rolling- I think it's cool because the length of the semi-ellipse is 2pi*radius. *Vibration Rotating imbalance- Without harmonic period of circular motion with initial speed with spring constant can be use to make the force system steady? *Car- This phenomena takes place with the selected speed of camera shutter? *Vibration Example 2. Does that mean we have to exert constant force in the same direction? 3. In x=0 and x=L/2? 4. Is the motion of B when A is on top and bottom due to constant gravity force of A? 5. It means rolling without slipping can eliminate the torque because the two equilibrium force is not balancing?

Please take some time to review these videos and see how what you are learning in the classroom applies to these situations.   Highlight Videos: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ED3LXV6JWCA https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kfECWaKQXSg Other Videos: Base-Excited Vibrations Centers of Mass Coefficient of Friction Conservation of Linear Momentum in a Ball Launcher Conservation of Linear Momentum in Inelastic Collisions Deflection in I-Beams Experimental Determination of Radius of Gyration Impending Motion of a Spool Rolling Without Slip Instantaneous Centers of Rotation of a Simple Mechanism Investigating Inertia Newton's Second Law - The Water Bucket Path Tracing on an Object Rolling Without Slip Rope-Pulley Kinematics Rotating Reference Frames - A Merry-Go-Round The Ballistic Pendulum The Dynamics Behind Impact Forces The Effect of Friction on a Falling Rigid Body The Natural Frequency of a Spring-Mass System The Vibration of Chladni Plates The Vibration of Strings The Work-Energy Equation - A Simple Rollercoaster Hill

item.title: Homework 1.A
item.dc:creator: jfrhoads
item.content:encoded: Here is a great place to discuss Homework 1.A.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: When is this due?
Everything will be discussed Monday in class regarding due dates.
We need to do implicit differentiation, giving an x dot and y dot in the velocity vector correct?
Actually for this one because x and y are explicit functions of time (pg 32 in the book) you can just directly differentiate each equation with respect to time.
Explicit differentiation CAN BE USED HERE.
Can someone please post the equations/rest of the problem? I went to order my book today and they are backordered and I am not sure it will be in by Wednesday. Thanks!
Is there an example homework that we can look at to double check our formatting and such?
Also, the solutions for this problem should be in vector form, correct? The second problem specified this but the problem above didn't so I want to make sure.
Can I express my answers in terms of i and j since we are given the horizontal and vertical components( x,y) ??
It's due at the beginning of your next class
Russel, I used to had this concern, but I found out that the homework appears on the right side of this page under course materials, open it up and you will see the whole thing
Just click on the homework tab at the top of the page.
Yeah, in my class it was on the back of one of the handouts Rhodes gave us.
Where can we find the engineering paper? Is it at the university book store?
Keep in mind that velocity and acceleration are vector quantities.
Yeah you can buy it there or Follets, any store like that.
Any of the local stores have it, or you can order it in bulk which can save you some money
Yes, the answer seems to be in vector form- using the unit vector notation should be just as valid
You can also find it on the blog under course information --> cover sheet

item.title: Homework 1.B
item.dc:creator: jfrhoads
item.content:encoded: Here is a great place to discuss Homework 1.B.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: for this one would it be correct to take the second derivative of y and plug in x = 2 into that? This would give you the y component of the acceleration, and the x component is given from the problem correct?
For this one, I think that y is a function of x and x is implicitly given as functions of t. Therefore you would have a x-dot at the end.
Can someone please post the equations/rest of the problem? I went to order my book today and they are backordered and I am not sure it will be in by Wednesday. Thanks!
Go to the section that says homework up top, that has the actual problems.
Would we use degrees or radians after double implicit derivation in the sin component?
I think we have to use Radians because x is given as 2
Anyone got huge values for the acceleration of the y-component ...?
Check out lecture example 1.A.2 if you would like to see a similar example.
Are we just supposed to leave the second derivation as is with the j unit vector component? How do we know if we're using degrees or radians in this problem?
You take the second derivate and then plug the x dot and the x values that were given in the problem.
I would say that we should probably use degrees since we are working with the Cartesian coordinate system for this problem.
There is a similar example on the bottom of page 32 that I found helpful.
i think its radians because it gave x=2 and not x=2 o
I was having trouble with units. ft^2/s^2 for acceleration? Anyone else have the same problem?
I found that very helpful - thanks for the post!

Acceleration would be in ft/s^2. (I don't know if this is valid) but if you think about it, a = (d/dt)^2 * r, more commo where r is position (a distance unit), and the dt is change in time (thus a time unit), so you would get a distance unit divided by a time unit squared.
Yes i got a high number

So what i got out of this question is that in using raw implicit differentiation one can find the answer quite easily: v(t)= a(t)=dv(t)/dt=d()/dt
You can set it up such that dy(x(t))/dt=dy/dx dx/dt That will find you the velocity for y(x(t)), reiterate to find that the acceleration is simply d(dy/dx dx/dt)/dx dx/dt.
From there its basically a plug 'n chug

Correction this thing doesnt show anything within the vector symbols so here it is:
v(t)=dx/dt i+ dy/dt j a(t)=dv(t)/dt=d(dx/dt i+ dy/dt j)/dt
Do I need to draw any graph for this question?
Hey Kim1719, I feel that if you want to make a graph then you can do so but it's not required. The graph would just the graph of function y = 3sin2x
Ensure you are properly integrating. x(dot) equals d/dt
No, you don't need to

item.title: Homework 1.C
item.dc:creator: jfrhoads

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Should we include the variable "r" in our answers or should we write out the full equation since r can be expressed in terms of theta?
Never mind, just read the entire problem.
I'm a bit confused, I'm getting units of meter*radians/sec in velocity. Are these the right units? What would that even mean?
The units for velocity should be meter/sec.

Angles are considered dimensionless, and the radians will be ignored; giving you meters/second.
http://mathforum.org/library/drmath/view/64034.html

A radian is define as arc length (of the circle) subtended by the angle, divided by the radius of the same circle.
Length divided by length is unitless, so you get m/s.
For the acceleration, how do we find r double dot?
Can i take the derivative or r(theta) with respect to time??

r double dot is the same as d(r dot)/dt.
so you need to take the time derivative of r dot. in doing this you will need to use the product rule since r dot involves both a theta and theta dot term

yes. However its not as simple as that. To get the derivative of r wrt t you need to take (dr/dtheta)(dtheta/dt) this expression is the same as dr/dt but correctly accounts for the fact that r is in terms of theta, rather than t
Anyone has the final answer? Just wanna know if i'm right or wrong?
derivative the position is the velocity, once more is the acceleration

item.title: Homework 1.D
item.dc:creator: jfrhoads
item.content:encoded: Here is a great place to discuss Homework 1.D.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: When calculating r-dot and r-doubledot for this problem, do you take the derivative with respect to theta or with respect to t?
Take the derivative of r with respect to t
What should the final units be since we never got units for r?
Unless anyone else has heard something, I'm going to use "units" as a generic measurement.
Did you get the chance to ask the professor about this??

No, but what we're interested in is the relation between Velocity/Acceleration and time. If you were to look exclusively at dr/d, then you'd be looking at the change with respect to the angle. In that case you wouldn't be accounting for the change in over time.
PART of the problem is finding dr/d, but there's more to it than that.
So if it is the derivative of r with respect to t, should R=theta^2 be substituted using theta=(t^2)/2?
For a problem like this, do we need to have anything for the "sketch" part of the specified homework format?
Correct, once that's done you can easily take the derivative with respect to time.
I'm also wondering about that

item.title: Homework 1.E
item.dc:creator: jfrhoads

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: When finding values for phi prime and phi double prime, would we need to use the derivative of phi=tan^-1(xp/yp)?

I was using the polar equations for v and a to solve for phi...does that work? Or is it different because e_phi ends up going the opposite direction as the normal orientation of the e_angle vector? (does that question even make sense?)
I was thinking R can be found by sqrt((15^2)+(20^2)) to get 25. and then r= 25(90-phi) what do you think?
How are we supposed to find the cartesian components without a given angle?
phi = tan^(-1)(15/20) from the image
They give us the cartesian components at the bottom of the page.
Do we somehow use the polar unit vectors e_R and e_phi to find the numerical values for R, phi, etc? I don't know how these are useful for us.
I found the alternate approach in the motivating example on page 52 as well as the information on the bottom on page 53 to be all I needed to solve the problem.
yes, you will have to relate the polar unit vector to the cartesian unit vector to find the values for R, phi and etc. you can use projection method ie. er= sin(phi) i +cos(phi)j for example
Can someone explain how the equations at the bottom of page 53 are derived? Why use dot products?
Because it's how vectors are projected onto other vectors. It's something that's taught in Calc 3
the units for phi dot can be degrees per second right?

You guys can just substitute for sin phi and cos phi with their respective values: xp/R and yp/R This should make it simpler- also one can find the radius of curvature using the formula |a|^2=vdot^2+(v^2/R)^2
Or just find R using pythagorean theorem on the coordinates
Also a quick note: Rdot should = vp dot eR, Rdotdot=ap dot eR Same for phidot and phidotdot

item.title: Homework 1.F
item.dc:creator: jfrhoads

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: In the example on page 53 of the lecture book it shows how to find the speed if the velocity is given in cartesian coordinates. It uses v=sqrt(xdot^2 + ydot^2). However, for this problem we have to go from polar->path. Is it valid to use v=sqrt(rdot^2 + (r*thetadot)^2) because they are still the components of the speed?

I just solved for x dot and y dot.
Are we to assume theta is 36.87 because that is what all the examples in the book use? Or is there a way to calculate it.
I think we can use v=sqrt(rdot^2 + (r*thetadot)^2) because of the "velocity is velocity" idea.
Yeah, I just used what Julie pointed out.

I don't know if we can do that since the question is asking us for that for the "path" of P. So I think we need to put v and a in terms of path coordinates, since e_r and e_theta is not necessarily the same as e_t and e_n.
So I'm asking: is the question prompting us to write v and a in terms of path components?
Or do we just need to calculate the scalar (which the comments above accomplish)?
OH it says "speed" and rate of change of "speed" so it's a scalar! Figured it out :)

Sorry for my constant commenting! But each description for cartesian, path, and polar velocities and accelerations work because the unit vectors are simply that: unit vectors! So the magnitude of the velocity of acceleration won't change across different coordinate systems.
is there a need to find theta? I found my rate of change of speed= 4 sin theta and radius of curv= -4/50^2 cos theta

I looked it up online and from what I can tell, it looks valid. What it said online was "The magnitude of the acceleration vector is a=[(a_t)^2+(a_n)^2]^.5" Since v is the same in each of the three forms, as well as a is the same in each of the forms (according to page 51), I'm assuming that it is valid to take the square root of the components in any form to get the speed.

I took the magnitude of the given velocity to find the speed. Then I found the tangent unit vector for the path description in terms of the 2 polar unit vectors by setting eT = (30eR - 40eTheta)/speed. I then solved for the rate of change of speed v-dot (the acceleration in the unit tangent direction), by setting v-dot equal to the acceleration vector dotted with the tangent unit vector.
The normal unit vector in the path description is the negative reciprocal of the tangent vector. Then I found the radius of curvature P by taking speed^2/P = the acceleration vector dotted with the normal unit vector and solved for P.

Yes, what Shahob said is right. An easier way to find radius of curvature might be to consider the path description components of acceleration. (e-t and e-n components)
We know |a| = |-4| = 4, and we just found v-dot (the e-t component of acc). So we can use pythagoras theorem to find the e-n component.
So v^2/rho = sqrt (a^2 - v-dot^2)

How can we say eT = (30eR - 40eTheta)/speed, when the book says that v*eT = rdot*eR + r*thetadot*eTHETA. We aren't given any information about theta so how can we solve it?
Is rate of change of the speed just 4?
In order to find the e_n unit vector, is that simply the normal of e_t unit vector? Or is it different for this problem?
Is there some way to find theta for this problem? It seems like we need a value for theta in order to get numerical solutions when calculating rate of change of speed and radius of curvature?

I also got my rate of change of speed to equal 4sin(theta), and my radius of curvature is in terms of theta as well, although I got 625/cos(theta) for that. Does anyone know if the answer is supposed to be in terms of theta or is the theta supposed to somehow cancel out in the calculations? Or is there some way to find what the value of theta is?

Shahob's comment above is the correct way to solve. You do not need to know theta because it is not needed for solving. When using the unit vectors, theta is not needed. V-dot (rate of change of speed) is not just 4, though. From the lecturebook on page 53, the motivating example helps provide the equation v-dot = e_t a. Use that to solve for v-dot once you find e_t.
There shouldn't be any need to calculate theta, or x dot and y dot for that matter. Which part are you trying to find?

Speed and rate of change of speed are different from v and a, assuming you mean the vectors. It'd be fine to use the square root calculation to find the magnitude of any velocity vector, no matter what form it is fine.

Speed is the magnitude of velocity and rate of change of speed does not equal acceleration. It can be found through the dot product of the (acceleration vector) and (unit path vector et). This was a proven by professor rhoads in class.

Magnitude of the acceleration is 4, but the rate of change of speed is not. It can be calculated by taking the dot product of acceleration and et(path unit vector). Magnitude of acceleration is not rate of change of speed.
Yes, I solved it using the theta value you gave.

item.title: Homework 1.G
item.dc:creator: jfrhoads

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: For this one, do we have to multiply SA by 2 where it goes from D to C, and do we include the wire from the wrap at D to A as part of L ?
The wrap around is a constant so it will fall out eventually. And yes since there are 2 wires that include the distance Sa, multiply by 2.
For the length from C to B should we take the magnitude of that wire, meaning d^2 + Sb^2 and the square root?
To find the length, yes. It's a hypotenuse. Then you have to calculate the rate at which that rope is being pulled by block B at this instant.

It's not so much of magnitude as it is Pythagorean Theorem. We're trying to find the movement in the X direction but the "d" is constant. Only Yb changes. So the hypotenuse is a function of CB in terms of the changing variable Yb.
On that note, how does the speed of the rope moving past C relate to the speed Vb?
Since Sb is the only thing that changes with respect to time, does that mean we take the derivative of sqrt(d^2+Sb^2) or just the derivative of Sb?
You'll need to take the derivative with respect to time of sqrt(d^2+Sb^2), treating d as a constant and Sb as a variable.

John, I believe in order to relate C to speed Vb, you need to put the length of the rope in terms of sqrt(d^2+Sb^2), then take the derivative. When you take the derivative, you will then have Sb dot, which is the velocity given at the beginning of the problem

That is what I am assuming. I am getting 1.5 for the speed . I am confused if there are any directions because taking speed from the velocity found just removes the negative. And there were no directions at ay point at all.
You forgot to multiply the answer by S_b as it is part of the derivative
Do we not need to know Sa to solve the problem? Or are we supposed to solve for it?
I answered my own question. Disregard this

item.title: Homework 1.H
item.dc:creator: jfrhoads

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: In part B to find the radius of curvature, would you use the e(normal) value you find in part A for the acceleration?

To find the radius of curvature use the motivating example found on page 53 to help you. It gives you the proper equation to use once you have found the v dot.
magnitude of a^2 = vdot^2+ (v^2/rho)^2
I found v by finding the magnitude of velocity. How do I find v_dot? I understand how to find rho once I have v_dot, but I need to find the latter first.
In the problem statement for part A it says "Boat B is traveling...with a constant speed of vB". The constant speed part means v_dot for boat B should be zero.
I haven't gotten to that part of the problem yet but remember: v_dot =/= acceleration. That's stated in the beginning of the chapter.
Also keep in mind this radius of curvature is relative to boat A. So V and A are both relative with B/A. But I am also confused on how to find Vdot at the moment.

I believe to find V_dotB/A you can use:
V_dot = ehat_t*a and ehat_t = velocity/ speed

Start with the acceleration equation( we can use the simplified version given on page 89 because we are working with a 2D problem) and plug in what we are given in the question(position vector and acceleration at a is zero). Then work through the cross product. Then make the 2 scalar equations separating the terms in the i and j direction and set them equal to the acceleration of point C that we are given in the problem. Basically what i figured out after a couple of iterations trying this problem out is that using the equation on page 87 (or so) and a substitution, one can get the equation: a*_b = a*_a + (alpha* X r*_b/a) - omega^2 (r*_b/a) Where asterisk signifies a vector. You can now break this vector down into scalar components after computing the basic cross products
(Remember the recycling method: iXj=k, jXk=i kXi=j and so the inverse direction gives you the negative unit vector) [also in this process it is good to remember that the omega and alpha are in the k direction, so pulling out all unit vectors leaves their scalar components] After this process you get all the i components in one equation and all the j components in another- a system of equations equal to the components of the acceleration, which is given. With this, all components of r are given (the base (x) and height(y) of the rectangular plate)- and given this you will have a system of equations: two equations and two unknowns. The page 93 example helps out, though the online workout of the problem is much easier to understand (just go to videos).

Yes, the acceleration of circular motion at constant speed is not zero. There might not be change in speed but the velocity is constantly changing as the path curves

To clear things up for readers: remember that the motion of D in in a semi-circle: centripetal acceleration takes into effect. This means that the formula: a_D=vdot e^(t)+v^2/r e^(n) takes into effect- vdot being the change of D's velocity with respect to time, in the tangent direction of the path. This is zero since the change in D's velocity is zero, but the second component of the acceleration will contribute by forcing an acceleration in the j direction toward the origin of the circle. Unless is specifically states, this should always be used for circular path motion.
Ps some hints: do in respect to a stationary point such as A, work your way to point B, then point D from there- it takes only a few steps to do this via omega and alpha equations. Also remember that all vector equations can decay into their equivalent scalar counterparts in each unit vector direction (i, j, k)

I used Integral(F*dr). F = -Fi = -6i The curve can be parameterized by r(t)=2cos(t)i+2sin(t)j where t goes from pi/2 to pi. You take the derivative dr/dt of r and then use that in the integral. Integral( -6i * ( -2sin(t)i + 2cos(t)j ) )dt from pi/2 to pi. The j term drops out due to the dot product and you are left with integral( 12sin(t) )dt = -12cos(t) evaluated from pi/2 to pi. Basically, solving problem like this type asking for Vr(speed in the direction of e_r),we have to first find out the speed in the direction of e_0 and then use the work-energy equation to look for e_r at the instant 2. The whole idea behind this is that the angular momentum equation is not able to tell us the speed in the same or opposite direction because such speed will be canceled out whenever we do the cross product calculation; therefore, the work-energy equation will help us once we find the speed V_0. By doing some analysis, we noticed that the resultant force on the particle is the spring force. However, it does not change the angular momentum of the particle since it is always in the same direction as the radius.(pay attention to the cross product equation related to angular impulse-momentum) Thus, the angular momentum is conserved(constant), which gives us HO1 = HO2. Then we will figure out the angular speed at instant 2.( Be careful to the radius at both instants) Well, all the rest is what we should be familiar with.

fische23, initially, R_dot will be zero because there is no component of velocity in the radial direction. After you solve for w2 using the angular momentum equation, you will use the Work-Energy equation to solve for a non-zero R_dot at instance 2.
